Description: Lamp with incised lines. A small mould-made oil-lamp of brick-red clay with black surface all over, with double-convex body with sharp carination, long nozzle oval in section with a rounded end, plain, small volutes in relief on boths sides at junction with body. The filling-hole is surrounded by a wide, flat rim from which radiate many incised grooves decorating the shoulder; on top of which, on one side, there is a semi-circular multiple-arched decoration. The base is ringed and slightly indented. Incrustations at edge of nozzle from use.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Later 2nd to 1st century BC parallel from Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, Figs 12a, 13g, see 11a), Athribis and other Egyptian sites (Mlynarczyk 1997, 142, Type L-prime, Fig. 129, see also 126). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould- made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.036) (Phase 3)
